It's a common misbelief that the SEC alone decides if a token is a security or not.

That's wrong. The SEC only decides its own enforcement strategy. If a token issuer disagrees, it can take the SEC to court where a judge or jury makes the decision (& the SEC doesn't always win).

1113469444628652038.text: 22/ IN CONCLUSION, the framework is definitely a cumulation of the cautionary lessons that we've learned from the SEC's past enforcement actions (don't shill your token $ value, actually develop a usable token, have a real plan to decentralize out your team, etc).

1113469443852648453.text:
21b/

(real talk im tired)

1113469443139612673.text:
21a/ 

+ token holders can immediately use it for its intended functionality
on the network

+ if the issuer facilitates the creation of a secondary market, transfers of the digital asset may only be made by and among users of the platform

1113469442514669568.text:
21/ To wrap it up, what are some things that make the tokens LESS likely to be a security under the Howey test?

+ both network and token fully functional and decentralized.
+ Prospects for appreciation in the token are limited (ie people dont expect to HODL for $$$)

1113469441008898054.text:
20/ Important question: what if the token sale was a security (and you didnt register), but now you truly think that your tokens should be re-evaluated since you really don't think it's a security in its form today? *uhemETHERuhem*

Consider these factors then:pic.twitter.com/gpy4bf9R5P

1113466487220703232.text: 19/ Some pretty obvious examples (translating the legalese): If you, as an issuer, successfully shill tf out of your tokens, that's creating a reasonable expectation of profit for your bagholders. If you as an issuer create a trading market for the token, same thing.

1113466484406222848.text: 18/ Under the Howey test, if an asset price appreciates as a result solely from external market forces (such as general inflationary trends or the economy), that's not profit. I'm not going into all the factors, but think about what DRIVES your token price appreciation.pic.twitter.com/IX81u50EI2

1113466480878866432.text: 17/ Let's now move onto "Reasonable Expectation of Profits" bc lol this fund never ends (and now that I am accountable I can't give up half way)pic.twitter.com/24WA2buA95

1113464608474505216.text: 16/ Points 13-16 really is to say: the SEC has some ideas as to what a 'decentralized network' looks like, and if you have a team who not only issues, sells, and promotes the tokens but also engages in the above, that's (obviously) not decentralized enough.

1113464607786639360.text: 15/ An affiliated party are those who created a market for the price of the digital assets (ie limiting supply through buybacks, burning), or plays a lead or central role in deciding governance issues, code updates, etc.

1113464607161618432.text:
14/ The SEC does acknowledge that development and the like may be done by a decentralized network. but if you have a core team that really does most of the development, improvement (or enhancement), operation,
or promotion of the network, that's when you need to be careful.

1113464606381441026.text: 13/ If you, as the purchaser of the tokens-- reasonably rely on others-- SEC defines it as a promoter, sponsor, or other third party (or affiliated group of third parties) -- to take on significant developments/ changes to the network, that meets most of it. *Keyword: affiliated*

1113464605685293057.text:
12/ The third prong of the Howey test *i.e. Reasonable Expectation of Profits Derived from Efforts of Others", is the more complicating factor. 

Some important considerations: reliance on others to make your tokens more valuable is generally what they mean by this.

1113461402709188611.text: 11/ We know already that each analysis is highly dependent on the facts and circumstances. The first two elements of the Howey test are also the easier ones to analyze: did you sell tokens for $$, and was there a central team developing it? The SEC thinks that most cases, yes.pic.twitter.com/WnstBoFmQP

1103679327789563910.text: 12/ To me, these reports show that we still have so much work to do on narratives, education, and UX/UI. Given how low trust is in mainstream media, we have an opportunity (and responsibility!) as an industry to push better and accurate information out to the broader market.

1103679327009423360.text: 11/ I definitely appreciated these two reports that the FCA commissioned. They were fair, asked good questions, and did not end with any over-hyped dangers to the overall markets, or how we should stay away from crypto assets.

1103679325470117890.text:
10/ This part is really important: 

Most consumers used Coinbase to buy their crypto because it was often referenced in media. BUT!!  Although some people wanted to use platforms other than Coinbase, they were often unable to understand how they worked.

OK HI UX/UI IMPORTANCEpic.twitter.com/lUZyvleYvq

1103679324593491968.text: 9/ Majority of those buyers first heard about crypto from friends/family who claimed to have made a profit. Asked about the sources that they trust re: cryptoassets, most agreed that they distrust mainstream media coverage (but were confident in their own 'instincts').

1103679323377201154.text:
8/ Now onto the in-depth interviews conducted towards those who either hold crypto or are seriously thinking about buying crypto. (Sample size: 31)

Most of their reasons for buying: to make short term profits, or because of FOMO.

1103679321804341248.text: 7/ One quick note: this shows to me that there is still very much a huge issue with the way that we discuss crypto, particularly to average consumers who have no idea how to think about this industry and the various crypto assets.

1103679317542866944.text: 6/ That being said, the general attitude towards cryptocurrency is quite friendly. 71% of crypto owners agreed that a cryptocurrency purchase is a risk they are willing to take. 62% believe that they are alternative investments to those offered in mainstream finance (!)pic.twitter.com/dpuaQriC0U

1103679316599193600.text: 5/ Many also seemed to have a sense that they were investing in tangible assets, due to the language and imagery associated with cryptoassets, such as ‘mining’ and ‘coin’.

1095774727073906690.text:
Since I can't help but tie everything to questions in crypto-building: 

Think about your users, and not in an abstract way. Find ways to engage with them & get their feedback.

Most importantly, humanize your product. Tech != impersonal, and crypto is a people-powered ecosystem.

1095774726302195712.text: Shipping product is important, but so is meaningful engagement with your users/ consumers/ potential hires. I remember seeing a job posting once and there was a section for 'Who you will be working with' w/ people profiles. Great move to humanize the recruiting process.

1095774725505236997.text: Glossier's "every single person is an influencer" marketing take is also super thoughtful. For example, before I buy something, I would totally trust a stranger's review over an algo recommended product. Using your consumers as your spokesperson > paying for celebrities.

1095774724787982336.text: And Glossier is actively building out a platform *for* their users. What Glossier does really well is serving the customer to interact with each other. In stores or online, people are answering each other's questions about the product. IMO that's just brilliant.

1095774723944927232.text: As we move more towards 'digital everything', I think that humanizing a process-- any process, really-- will become even more important. The magic of Glossier is really in capturing that sort of authenticity that consumers/ users have started to crave more.

1095774723152195584.text:
Glossier's "cult-like" consumer following is built on top of those two main points. When users feel heard and connected, they are more likely to engage and share feedback. 

The point "Amazon really solved buying, but it killed shopping in the process" totally resonated with me.

1095774722346926082.text:
I finally had a chance to listen to @karaswisher interview @EmilyWWeiss (CEO of Glossier), two major takeaways:

+ Your users = your lifeline
+ Humanity is extraordinarily important in connecting with your users (this is especially important for tech companies)

Anyway, I know there is a ton more to this debate. Open to book recs on this topic!

If you're looking for something to do this weekend, Professor Lessig (the author) made the entire "Code v2" book free in PDF form here: 

http://www.codev2.cc/download+remix/Lessig-Codev2.pdf …

1094316045182083073.text: The complicated thing is that-- your phone contains sensitive records that will reveal far more information than the most exhaustive search of your house. How can that sort of broad power be limited by your right to privacy as under the fourth amendment?

1094316044498423809.text: But emails are instantaneous and happen along machine communications. And to confine the corners of machine communication within laws that are for the physical space is difficult. Then you throw in stuff like: passcode locks on your phone, encryption, P2P file sharing, etc.

1094316043818930176.text: When it comes to the internet and networks, the line between privacy and open/public information is much harder to define. For example, letters in transit are not expected to have a right to privacy, because the intermediaries are human (mailman) and prone to delivery errors.

1094316043160436736.text: In other words-- in the physical world, the expectation of privacy hinges on two major factors: 1. The subjective expectation of privacy, and 2. The expectation that society is willing to recognize as reasonable.

1094316042304843779.text: In the physical world, the line between privacy and open/public information is pretty obvious- when you close the door to your apartment (h/t @soonaorlater for that comparison), you have that reasonable expectation of privacy.

1094316041013026818.text: The online world and the “real” world are different in many respects, and the rules that apply to searches in the “real” world cannot simply be applied to digital searches — whether searches of online networks or searches of physical computers.

1094316039956033539.text:
"Code v2" by @lessig -- even after all these years -- is still such a thought-provoking read. 

One major question I've been pondering lately: how should the fourth amendment protections against unreasonable search and seizures extend to the digital space?

1088203200610463745.text: 9/ Though other regulators in the world still look to the U.S. regulators and their crypto guidance as a reference, it's clear that they are taking one step forward and issuing sandboxes, regulations, or guidance without waiting around.

1088203200086269952.text: 8/ The U.S. government shutdown will result in so much backlog and delays across all sectors- I am pessimistic about any meaningful progress that could be made on the crypto frontier once everything is back up and running (if ever..)

1088203199503163392.text: 7/ But this also may be how and why other countries (particularly SE Asia or HK/Taiwan) can jump into the crypto sector by providing frameworks and guidance that are easier to navigate or, in some cases, construct from ground zero.

1088203198895013888.text: 6/ The SEC has been so vilified by the crypto-community in the U.S. due to definitions that are rooted in the way that the legal structure is set. The U.S. legal system is based on precedents, and to overrule that usually takes a shit ton of time and legal resources.

1088203198332981248.text: 5/ In addition, Hong Kong has launched sandboxes for crypto exchanges, and seem fairly willing to work with the crypto community to shape the regulations into something that makes more sense (likely in response to criticism that the regulations are too hard to comply w)

1084479161836687362.text: 10/ Two more things: the rules encourage self-regulation as a way to increase legitimacy for the blockchain/crypto industry. Also, to go the ICP registration path is actually a lot more flexible for blockchain companies to continue to operate in China, since burden to do is low.

1084479161027178496.text: 9/ Most of these regulations are not that out of the norm for any internet companies in China, but I think the one problematic point is the way that the rule over "users" is written, as it includes community members of a crypto project (even if the project is based abroad!)

1084479160309952514.text: 8/ This also imposes certain recordkeeping requirements, including having a copy of a 6-month log of user content and comments (this probably includes community members in a slack/discord). These records will be turned over to relevant agencies if an investigation opens.

1084479159433416704.text: 7/ Also: any "blockchain service provider" must *not* service users who do not provide information to verify their real identity (i.e. phone #, ID #, or their company ID #. This is common for most internet companies in China, but could be difficult here.

1084479158745526274.text: 6/ Think of it as a 'give us your company + officer information so you can do business in China as an internet content provider and so we have someone to go after if there is anything shady/illegal that result from your services"

1084479158082781185.text: 5/ There isn't really a good way to translate the ICP registration since there is no Western equivalent. Basically, it is primarily aimed to eliminate illicit activities done on a specific platform. Cost to register is zero, and the information is mostly contact-based.

1084479157394919424.text: 4/ In order to obtain such a license, companies will have to abide by certain requirements, such as providing information on its business name, service type, ID addresses, service jurisdiction within 10 business days of service.

1084479156640014338.text: 3/ China will be regulating crypto companies via its ICP registration process, which is its way of regulating most internet companies in China. So, in order to do business in China, blockchain companies will have to register for an ICP (Internet Content Provider) license.

What does this Supreme Court case mean?

1079350399994228736.text:
Some courts (second & ninth circuit) think that the anti-retaliation protection extends to those who made reportings internally as well as those to report to the SEC. 

The Fifth Circuit thinks that only those to report to the SEC should be protected. The Supreme Court agreed.

1079350397335068678.text:
By the way, for those interested in U.S. legal/policy developments:

17/ Looking ahead: lawyers think traders are next in line to be targeted for crypto enforcement actions. Public reports of market manipulation are common & the government is apparently investigating.

If that happens, don't forget what went down when the CFTC came for DRW.

1070119025496207360.text: 16/ BTW looks like DRW was defended by Kobre & Kim (shoutout to @jchervinsky’s law firm!)

1070119023566835713.text:
15/ So what does this all mean? 

Aside from setting important precedent for market manipulation cases under the Commodity Exchange Act, this case shows that government enforcement agencies like the CFTC & SEC do not make the law. They can get it wrong & they can lose in court.

1070119021721329664.text: 14/ (cont) “It is only the CFTC's Enforcement Division that has persisted in its cry of market manipulation, based on little more than an 'earth is flat'-style conviction that such manipulation must have happened because the market remained illiquid. Clearly, that is not enough.”

1070119019846557696.text:
13/ Judge concludes: 

"[i]t is not illegal to be smarter than your counterparties . . . nor is it improper to understand a financial product better than the people who invented [it]. . . . There is absolutely no evidence to suggest that [DRW] ever [manipulated the market.]"

1070119018068103168.text:
12/ And he also confirmed that DRW was right all along in its assessment of the IDCH contract's true value.

He said the CFTC's expert testimony on this issue was "absurd." He said it had "no basis in law or logic and was contradicted by the contract's very terms[.]" 

Lol DAMN

1070119016272932864.text:
11/ Then he concluded that the CFTC had failed to prove intent anyway, saying:

"[T]he trial testimony and exhibits prove beyond the shadow of a doubt that [DRW] sincerely believed the fair market value of the . . . Contract was higher than the bids [it] submitted[.]"

1070119014523985922.text:
10/ The judge rejected the CFTC's theory, holding that they failed to prove the IDCH contract price was artificial. After all, DRW's bids reflected "true value."

He called the CFTC's logic "conclusory and circular," saying "artificiality is not proven or disproven by intent."

1070119012720353280.text:
9/ The case went to trial on December 1, 2016. It was a bench trial, meaning the judge alone was responsible for deciding the outcome (no jury).

The trial lasted four days, and then we waited nearly two years for the final decision.

1070119011013279744.text:
8/ The CFTC's argument went something like this:

- DRW intended its bids to influence the contract price;
- That factor alone caused the price to be artificial; so
- DRW’s bids were inherently manipulative.

DRW took the position of course that its trading strategy was lawful.

1070119009163591680.text:
7/ As a legal matter, the CFTC had to prove four elements to establish market manipulation:

(1) DRW had the ability to influence price
(2) an artificial price existed
(3) DRW caused the artificial price
(4) DRW intended to cause the artificial price

1070119007053864963.text:
6/ So, DRW unwound its open positions for a profit, its counterparties admitted defeat ("You won big. We lost big") and IDCH cancelled the contract.

That should be the end of the story, but instead, the CFTC concluded (wrongly) that DRW's strategy was market manipulation.

1070119004998643712.text:
5/ This strategy had the effect of increasing the contracts’ settlement price and, in turn, the value of DRW's portfolio.

DRW continued buying contracts at prices below its estimate of true value until August 2011, when IDCH realized DRW was right: the contract was faulty.

1070119002893103105.text:
4/ So DRW's strategy involved bidding for contracts at a price slightly higher than the OTC swaps but lower than its estimate of the contracts’ true value.

As time went on, DRW continually increased the price of its bids to find additional counterparties willing to trade.

1070119000972120064.text: 3/ Basically...DRW, through quantitative analysis, determined that the true value of the IDCH contract was significantly higher than that of comparable OTC swaps. This created an arbitrage opportunity that DRW started trading in August 2010.

1070118999101489152.text: 2/ As background: the CFTC brought this enforcement action against DRW in November 2013, alleging that it manipulated the price of an exchange-cleared three-month interest rate swap futures contract listed by the International Derivatives Clearinghouse (IDCH).

1064357626815938560.text: 22/ I appreciate that the IMF dedicated the time and resources to do the research and consider this topic, but taking out the cross-border implication out was such a cop-out. Plus there were a lot of assumptions about crypto that were super off base or missed the point.

1064357625742139392.text: 21/ So ultimately, does CBDC offer net benefits? The IMF concludes that it is too early to draw firm conclusions on the net benefits of CBDC. Plus, it’s not that much more compelling than evolving commercial bank deposits and e-money.

1064357624689434624.text: 20/ A huge cite of concern: financial integrity, which I think pretty much refers to how much control authorities can have over the CBDC, specifically around issues of due diligence (AML) and privacy safeguards.

1064357620084027392.text: 19/ On the public policy side, while central banks could benefit from CBDC to more fully satisfy some of the social criteria of money (I.e. the decreasing use of cash), it’s not better than regulation and faster payment platforms.

1064357618989305856.text:
18/  Note at the end: "Cryptocurrencies are the least attractive [alternative] option, receiving a low score in settlement speed because of current technological limitations...Their main advantage is anonymity.” 

No comments from me, just leaving this here for you all.

1064357618016231425.text: 17/ Of course, this is not a surprising narrative from the IMF on cryptocurrencies, given the Central’s Banks’ criteria in evaluating money to begin with, plus literally, it's entire reason for existing...

1064357615222820870.text: 16/ The IMF paper points to stable coins as examples of cryptocurrencies that "stabilize their value by controlling issuance according to a function of price deviations from a fiat currency or commodity”.

1064357613314473984.text: 15/ What does the IMF think about the proliferation of crypto? Brushes it off, since crypto "struggles to fully satisfy the functions of money, in part because of erratic valuations”. Plus, “these currencies are not the liability of any institution and are not backed by assets.”

1064357610856566785.text: 14/ In economics, money is seen as having three functions: a unit of account, a means of payment, and a store of value. The case for CBDC is really on whether it seems to strengthen those functions for users and for central banks.pic.twitter.com/pVa2TksRpA

1064357607152996352.text: 13/ Also, settling a transaction using token based CBDC would require external verification of the tokens. As a result, transactions might not be entirely anonymous. The extent of anonymity would depend on whether wallets are registered and transaction information is recorded.

1064357604342804481.text: 12/ What would a CBDC look like? Here's a comparison of either an account or token based CBDC. Decentralized settlement currently falls short in scalability, energy efficiency, and payment finality— centralized settlement technology would likely more efficient.pic.twitter.com/BfK4UPSrTt

1064357603109687297.text: 11/  CBDC is a new form of money, issued digitally by the central bank and intended to serve as legal tender. As a result, the IMF agrees that this means that change in legislation would be required.

1064357601033502721.text: 10/ Major caveat: the IMF paper abstracts from cross-border considerations by assuming that CBDC is for domestic use only. So, it’s country-specific and would largely depend on how each central banks will approach the design. So not what we think of as "crypto" in this industry.

1064357599699763200.text: 9/ Moving onto the IMF paper now, which is titled "Casting Light on Central Bank Digital Currencies”. Kicks off with: how should central banks adapt to the digitization of economic activity? Their answer? A Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC).

1064357598667911169.text: 8c/ Lagarde proposes public-private partnerships, where the central bank focuses on its comparative advantage—back-end settlement—and financial institutions and start-ups are free to focus on what they do best—client interface and innovation. Interesting......

1064357597489319936.text:
8b/ As a user of a non-state backed currency (I.e. bitcoin), why would I care if the central bank wanted to offer a full-service solution for fiat currency in digital form?? 

**thinks to the proliferation of stablecoins** oh, right. okay.

1064357596423995395.text: 8a/ I am confused as to Lagarde’s point on innovation actually. She asks “Where is your role if the central bank offers a full-service solution, from digital wallet, to token, to back-end settlement services?”, which is a question I found confusing.

1064357595002138624.text: 8/ Cons of a central bank digital currency: 1) risks to financial integrity (versus privacy); 2) risks to financial stability (translation: what’s the point of banks anymore? Ok this sounds like an existential crisis here) 3) Risks to innovation.

1064357592951070721.text: 7/ Pros of a central bank digital currency: 1) financial inclusion (ability to reach people in marginalized regions); 2) security and consumer protection; 3) privacy in payments (Lagarde did not seem to like this at all, using the ‘what if criminal use this’ example..lol ok?)

1064357587976691712.text: 6/  As we evolve into a digital economy, should central banks issue a new digital form of money? Lagarde believes that the IMF should consider the possibility to issue digital currency as there may be a role for the state to supply money to the digital economy.

1064357582104682496.text: 5/ Quote in Lagarde's speech where she addresses crypto: “Even cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Ripple are vying for a spot in the cashless world, constantly reinventing themselves in the hope of offering more stable value, and quicker, cheaper settlement."

1064357576752664578.text: 4/ The fintech revolution questions these two forms of money: coins and commercial bank deposits. And it also questions the role of the state in providing money.

1064357571312738305.text: 3/ I am starting with Lagarde’s speech first, which is focused on the changing nature of money. In short,  money itself is changing. In the increasingly digitalized world, we expect money to become more convenient, user-friendly, safe,  readily available for online & P2P use.

1055638539650633728.text:
18/ IN CONCLUSION: this is just one arbitrator’s view on bitcoin and the law but damn this was one fascinating read and made me want to hug the arbitrator and just say YOU GO GIRL (OR GUY) (OR MAGICAL UNICORN)

ps China does not hate bitcoin.

(thank you @nlw for paging me!!)

1055638538711154690.text: 17/ My fav sentence: "The Party contends that Bitcoin has characteristics of a property (SOV), can be controlled by the owner, and has economic value to the owner. It does not break any laws. This arbitrator agrees.”

1055638537834561538.text: 16/ Third, just because bitcoin is not a legally recognized currency does not mean that, as a *property* it should not be afforded legal protection.

1055638536970477569.text: 15/ Second point that the arbitrator makes: sure, bitcoin lives in the digital world and has diff. characteristics than fiat, but that does not stop it from being a form of payment.

1055638536026800128.text: 14/ So, just because a repayment contract between private parties involved bitcoin, does not mean that the contract is invalid.

1055638534307172352.text: 13/ In the arbitrator’s view, whether or not bitcoin is legal, the **circulation and the payment** of bitcoin is not illegal. Bitcoin does not have the same rights as fiat, but that does not mean that holding or paying w crypt is illegal.

1055638532956536832.text: 12/ Basically, the defendant tried to say that because ICOs are illegal, this entire contract should be void. The arbitrator disagreed with this.

1055638531769548800.text: 11/ Now that the facts are straight.. what did the arbitrator (reminder: this is a private settlement and not an official opinion from a judge) say???

1055638530041540608.text: 10/ HOWEVER, once B paid back A in full (in C’s behalf!!), C refused to give back the BTC/BCH/BCD. So B is made and wants the shares and the cryptoassets back.

1055638529273929729.text: 9/ Because of this profit, B agreed to pay back the remaining $300,000 to A on behalf of C while C kept managing the crypto assets.

1055638528493846528.text: 8/ Now, B had ask C to manage his/her bitcoin (and other cryptoassets), which saw profits over the disputed time period.

1055638527541735424.text: 7/ Party A is a Partnership, Parties B & C are natural persons. Under the agreement, C held 5% of the partnership’s shares ($550,000 in RMB), and paid back 250k of that to A.

1055638526681845762.text: 6/ The amount of assets at dispute: 20.13BTC、50BCH、12.66BCD. (Plus interest in USD)

1055638525683658752.text: 5/ Facts of this case is a little much to get into, but it involved disagreement over a share transfer agreement that was signed between three parties (A, B and C).

1055638524781887488.text: 4/ Aside from the existing laws, the arbitrator also relied on the “spirit of the original agreement” as well as the “original intent" of the parties & determined that bitcoin has *property rights* and thus should be protected under the law.

1055638523850690561.text: 3/ Because the various legal definitions for crypto under current Chinese laws and regulation are unclear, the arbitrator relied on existing contract law and general provisions of the civil law to determine the contract that is at dispute here.

1055638522349191168.text: 2/ BTW IN CASE THERE IS ANY CONFUSION ON THE LEGAL IMPLICATIONS: arbitrators do **NOT** make laws. So please do not interpret this one arbitration decision as an official legal rule change. But this is still important. Read on for the arbitrator’s rationale..

1055638520440766471.text: 1/ The official account of the Shenzhen International Court of Arbitration released an explanation on a recent share transfer dispute that involved bitcoin, bitcoin cash, and bitcoin diamond & determined that crypto is protected under China’s current property & contract law.

11/ Text to the full draft guidelines are here (Chinese version only): http://www.cac.gov.cn/1123585598_15399442823981n.docx …

Keep in mind these are draft guidelines for now, and the comment period will be open for 10 business days. Staying tuned...

1054513064320647170.text: 10/ The major issue? These guidelines target “blockchain technology”, and assume central parties/ central points at any given point— but— given the decentralized nature of the tech— it’s hard to understand how these rules will get implemented.

1054513062496124929.text: 9/ Specifically, the guidelines target “information services”, which includes all kinds of information exchange and transmission, but does not specify what the technology is, or what information systems is it that the guidelines target.

1054513060667420672.text: 8/ Some critics of the draft have pointed out the dangers in trying to define “blockchain information services” too early on and making the definitions so broad as to include *any and all* blockchain-related services. (We’ve heard this argument before re: U.S. legislation too).

1054513059794968576.text:
7/ Plus, harsh penalties (fines/ shutting down/criminal penalties etc) for blockchain service providers that (among other requirements):

+ create, copy, or distribute any state-banned content 
+ do not verify user information
+ do not take steps to store transactions/information

1054513058880598017.text: 6/ Strict requirements (rule 9) around the service provider’s content management: specifically, over the dissemination, recording, saving, and broadcasting. Under these rules, they must all comply with current national laws and standards.

1054513058004025344.text: 5a/ BTW- I don’t think it's abnormal for any internet platform user in China. In order to use Didi (China’s Uber) or WeChat pay, users have to register this sort of information with the platform. Of course, this is just hard to implement on a **blockchain** for obvious reasons.

1054513057173569536.text: 5/ Rule 10 in the draft points to China’s Internet Safety Laws and will be mandating all blockchain information service providers and **users** to provide identification proof (by way of government issued ID or phone number) in order to use/access the service.

1054513054577319943.text: 4/ There are a few mains objectives as laid out in the guidelines: 1. to better define the scope of a “blockchain information service”; 2. To foster the growth of the industry;  3. To protect interests of citizens and 4. To protect the interest of the state.

1054513053620944896.text:
3/ This is China’s first attempt at both defining and setting the scope for the “blockchain information/ technology” category from a regulation aspect. 

(Link to the notice here: http://www.cac.gov.cn/2018-10/19/c_1123585598.htm …)

1054513052744343553.text: 2/ For background: China’s Office of the Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission (formed in 2014) is basically the regulator that has oversight in anything that is internet/ information-related— yes, that includes censorship/ information control/ etc.

1054513051884552192.text: 1/ China’s “Internet regulator” just put out draft guidelines for “blockchain information & related services” and are asking for public comments. This is China’s first regulatory attempt at defining & setting the scope for the “blockchain information/ technology” category.

1050405827469701120.text: 13/ So again, the full post flows better (I promise!). Check it out here :)https://twitter.com/MessariCrypto/status/1050403811888574471 …

1050405825498370049.text: 12/ Nothing wrong with the traditional private fundraising model in a legal sense, except that continues to shut out eligibility for the majority of people to be able to particulate in such investments. PLUS, the accredited investor definition has its own set of issues.

1050405824588173312.text: 11/ Token sales have introduced a new form of fundraising— or rather, a new form of crowdfunding. Due to the legal and regulatory considerations, token sales are falling back into the traditional private fundraising model, which has some issue in its framework.

1050405823787102208.text: 10/ BTW: misrepresenting your own investor status means it's most likely the issuer that gets screwed at the end because that then destroys their ability to rely on something like 506 (b) or (c) to fundraise. No one wins.

1050405822948290561.text: 9a/ (Plus, how would you standardized that and test for knowledge?)

1050405822126145536.text: 9/ Proposals to expand the accredited investor definition want to include experience, education, etc. But that to me seems to come back to the same question: why should my job/degree dictate my investment freedom and decision? Those also do not always equate to knowledge.

1050405821287260161.text: 8/ There has been a lot of (very understandable) frustrations, which boils down to this: why should how many money you make/ what your net worth is dictated what you are, or are not, allowed to invest in? Money does not equate to knowledge.

1050405820393910273.text:
7a/ Accredited investor reqs:

- Have a net worth of at least $1 million (excluding value of primary resident), 

OR

- Have earned income that exceeds $200,000 in each of the prior two years— and can expect the same for the current year (or, together with a spouse, $300,000)

1050405819521495040.text: 7/ Basically, if you cannot meet the accredited investor requirements, then you are excluded from investing into any companies that are raising their money via Rule 506 (c) (or, god forbid you are the 36th person to want to invest in a company relying on Rule 506 (b)!)

1050405818581975041.text: 6/ Thus, more issuers are relying on exemptions to securities registration. The problem is— over 99% of that Regulation D money is raised through Rule 506, which is pretty much the only rule that is the most inflexible when it comes to letting non-accredited investors invest.

1050405817768325120.text: 5/ Since the full implementation of the JOBS act, we have seen a number of companies that are choosing to defer their IPOs (relying instead on private financing). Example of high profile pre-IPO private placement include the likes of Pinterest, Uber, Spotify, Palantir, etc.

1050405816111489024.text: 4/ In 2017, the total amount in the U.S. raised through all private offering channels totaled over $ 3.0 trillion USD. Meanwhile, there has been a steady and significant decrease in the number of public reporting companies in the US, particularly since the dot-com crash + SOX.pic.twitter.com/Bo0ypfOd7c

1050405815239077888.text: 3/ To begin: A company or private fund may not offer or sell securities unless the transaction has been registered with the SEC OR if an exemption from registration is available.

1050405814358274049.text: 2/ Reminder: I’m not barred in any U.S. state and this is most definitely not legal advice (hire your own counsel guys), I hope these ramblings from a huge legal and policy nerd shed more light on a much discussed, but little-understood process.

1045090987301892097.text: TO CONCLUDE: I mean, personal opinions aside, Bitmain is one hell of a fucking company. These IPO documents contain an incredible wealth of information. Happy to answer anything specific if you have burning questions and I can look through the docs for you- otherwise, enjoy!

1045089953410162688.text:
Bitmain’s customer base:

+ From 6,000 customers in 2015 to 80,000 customers in just the first six months of 2018. 

+ 48.2% domestic sales, 51.8% international sales.

1045088903399649280.text:
Bitmain’s physical storage management:

+ As of June 2018, Bitmain has 7 garages located in Shenzhen, China. Those garages can store up to 1.5 million (!!)  mining rigs. Inventory includes mostly conductor components. 

(FYI accountants: inventory is accounted using FIFO.)

1045087292891820032.text: + Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (aka Taiwan Semiconductor) is Bitmain’s single largest supplier, accounting for 59.2% of Bitmain’s total supply in the first half of 2018. ( & 58.6% in 2017!)

1045086047712038912.text: Bitmain is currently considering setting up a mining farm in Canada’s Quebec province, which will operate on hydroelectric power.

1045085739308986368.text:
Bitmain’s mining farms outside of China:

+ There are three mining farms currently underway in the U.S.: Washington, Texas, and Tennessee. Expected operational date is 2019 Q1, and a maintenance/repair center will also be set up in Washington state.

1045084943418839041.text: + On pricing: “When pricing mining rigs, we consider the currency’s market price, competitive pricing, the forecasted revenue, the product model, and the need for the mining rig. We also employ a sliding pricing strategy, which is the norm for the industry."

1045084845649604608.text: + The core of Bitmain’s crypto mining services is in the front end + back end design of the ASIC chips and thus will be the major link to the ancillary businesses. Bitmain is currently in the process of developing the next generation of 7nm ASIC chips.

1045084844294893568.text:
Bitmain’s business lines:

+ ASIC chips for crypto mining and AI applications; the hardware that accompanies those, mining farms and operations, and other related crypto services.

1045072945146736640.text: (ok to be continued later my brain is melting i need a break)

1045072786199334913.text: + Bitmain want to continue to invest in AI and push AI development and application by way of their advantage in ASIC chip design. Areas of focus: augmented reality, facial recognition, and big data analysis.

1045071978560917504.text: + Bitmain also plans to increase its foothold in the blockchain ecosystem through increased partnerships as well as ramping up its own investment arm (I don’t know how much $$ they plan to pour into crypto startups, but probably a sizable amount).

1045071232570470402.text:
Bitmain's strategy:

+ Continue to invest in the research & development of chips— specifically, in ASIC chip design for crypto mining in order to increase computation efficiency while decreasing power watt usage. As such, Bitmain plans to hire aggressively towards that direction.

1045069766686371842.text:
Back to Bitmain:

+ As of June of 2018, Bitmain has a team of 840 (!!) full-time engineers. That is ~30% of its entire team. The focus: chip design, algo dev, platform design, software, and hardware development.

1045067925185540102.text: (cont. from above) However, the position of Bitcoin and other crypto assets are constantly changing under U.S. federal law and the various state laws. Jurisdiction of each cryptoasset is decided by the relevant U.S. regulatory agency, depending on the characteristics and usage."

1045067922933272576.text:
ON US REGULATION:

+ Bitmain addresses U.S. regulations (loosely translated): “We do not know of any U.S. federal laws that forbid the import of mining rigs from any natural persons or entity,  nor the selling or manufacturing of the mining rigs within its borders...

1045065303896588288.text: + Bitmain credits the increasingly popular crypto market for its own growth. It points to Coinbase’s growing user base as a statistic: Coinable users grew from 500,000 in 2013 to over 20 million users as of June 2018. (Even includes a nice chart for @coinbase here)pic.twitter.com/rmuTDvUhBg

1045063341679480832.text: + More specifically: Micree Zhan owns 36% of the current Bitmain shares, while Jihan Wu owns 20.25%.

1045059359955447808.text:
Details on the actual IPO: 

+ The Bitmain IPO plans to be listed on the Hong Kong Stock exchange via a weighted voting right structure. 

+ Two largest shareholders: Micree Zhan & Jihan Wu. Also: The CEO of Sogou (Chinese search engine) is among the largest shareholders.

1045059358772654080.text:
(Bitmain stats, cont.)

+ 3.3% of their revenue in 2018 thus far comes from self-mining.
+ Bitcoin currently has 11 mining farms in China, including Sichuan, Inner Mongolia, etc. Each mining farm can hold ~20,000 mining rigs.
